questions.text: Do you work or are you cared for/accommodated in one of the following areas?
Have two or more persons been tested positively for the novel coronavirus in the facility you live in or work for in the last 14 days?
Do you smoke?
Are you pregnant?
Have you had close contact with a confirmed case?
questions.details:
Close contact with a confirmed case means:
  • Face-to-face contact for longer than 15 minutes
  • Direct, physical contact (touching, shaking hands, kissing)
  • Being within 6 feet of the person for more than 15 minutes
  • Contact with or exchange of body fluids
  • Living in the same apartment.
Choose "No" if you have worn adequate protective measures (mask) on contact.

questions.text: What day was the last contact?

options.text: I don't use a contact tracing app

questions.text: Did you have an exposure notification of a digital contact tracing app in the last 14 days?
questions.details: Digital contact tracing apps track when people are in close contact and a recent contact tests positive.

questions.text: In the last days, which of the following symptoms have you had? (multiple selection possible)
questions.details: The question relates to acute or exacerbated symptoms and excludes chronic complaints or seasonal or allergic complaints. If you have a chronic illness, compare your current symptoms with your previous problems to answer the question.  If you haven't had any of the symptoms, choose the âNextâ button without selecting a symptom.

questions.text: In the last days, which of the following symptoms have you had? (multiple selection possible)
questions.details: If you haven't had any of the symptoms, choose the âNextâ button without selecting a symptom.

questions.text: In the past 24 hours, did you feel that you were more quickly out of breath than usual?
questions.details:
Choose âYesâ if you have difficulty breathing or shortness of breath:
  • While sitting or lying down
  • When getting up from a bed or a chair
  • After light activity, such as going for a walk or climbing some stairs.
If you have chronic lung disease, compare your current breathing problems with your previous breathing problems.

questions.text: With regard to all questions about symptoms: since when have you had the symptoms you specified?

options.text: Chronic lung disease (e.g. chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, asthma, interstitial lung disease, cystic fibrosis)
Heart disease (e.g. cardiovascular disease, congenital heart disease)
Having a medical-related technological dependence (e.g. tracheostomy, gastrostomy)

questions.details: We use your height and weight to calculate your body mass index (BMI). The BMI can be a risk factor in the context of COVID-19

questions.text: Do you currently receive one or more of the following treatments?
questions.details: You take or get immunosuppresives after an organ transplant, in the therapy of an autoimmune disease. Chemo and/or radiotherapy is used as treatment for cancer. If you don't receive any of these treatments, choose the âNextâ button without selecting a treatment.

Have you been vaccinated for the novel coronavirus?

questions.details: Select yes, if you have received a single-dose vaccine, such as the Johnson & Johnsonâs Janssen vaccine, or all doses of 2-doses vaccines, such as Pfizer or Moderna vaccines. Booster shots don't need to be considered.

results.text:
Based on your responses CovApp has created a personal risk profile which is also used for your recommendations.

The profile has four risk dimensions with a value between 0 and 100 points. While a lower score implies lower risk, higher scores indicate a higher risk. These scores are only intended to serve as a rough orientation without any guarantee.

These are the four risk dimensions:

1. Symptoms: This score increases if your responses indicate symptoms that can be related to COVID-19.

2. Exposition: This score increases if you have visits, encounters, or circumstances, which imply that you could have been in contact with the novel coronavirus.

3. Severe Course: This score increases if your responses indicate any circumstances (e.g. chronic diseases, medications, or similar) that increase your chance of a severe course if you are infected by the novel coronavirus.

4. Dissemination potential: This score increases, if you have a private or work-related environment that favors the spread of the virus if you are infected and infectious.

Symptom and Exposition scores are used together with your vaccination status to compile the "Test Recommendation". The score severe course is combined with your vaccination status for the "Recommendations for Severe COVID-19". The score dissemination potential is interpreted in combination with the probability of infection to create the "Recommendations to prevent spread of virus".

Your personal risk profile:

Symptoms: %(v_symptoms_user_score)d of 100 Points
Exposition: %(v_exposition_user_score)d of 100 Points
Severe Course: %(v_severity_user_score)d of 100 Points
Dissemination potential: %(v_dissemination_user_score)d of 100 Points

Most users with a negative PCR-test are not infected with the novel coronavirus. PCR-tests are a very reliable method to assess the infection status of a person with a high validity. If you encounter a risk contact or new symptoms after completion of your PCR-test, it might be senseful to repeat it. If you have further questions, please contact the facility which conducted the PCR-test.

Most users with a positive PCR-test are infected with the novel coronavirus. You are fully vaccinated, however breakthrough infections can occur.  If you have further questions, please contact the facility which conducted the PCR-test.

Most users with a positive PCR-test are infected with the novel coronavirus. Especially, at the beginning or the end of the infection there might be positive PCR-tests with a viral load below 1.000.000 copies/ml. In such a case, a comprehensive medical consultation is necessary. If you have further questions, please contact the facility which conducted the PCR-test.

Some users with your responses are infected with the novel coronavirus. For verficiation purposes we recommend a PCR-test which is more reliable than an antigen test. You are fully vaccinated, however breakthrough infections can occur.
Many users with your responses are infected with the novel coronavirus. For verficiation purposes we recommend a PCR-test which is more reliable than an antigen test.

Most users with your answers are not infected with the novel coronavirus. If you encounter a new risk contact or new symptoms, it might be senseful to repeat a test. In such a case, please complete the questionnaire of CovApp again to get an individualized recommendation.

Most users with your answers are not infected with the novel coronavirus. If you encounter a new risk contact or new symptoms, it might be senseful to repeat a test. In such a case, please complete the questionnaire of CovApp again to get an individualized recommendation.

Some users with your answers are infected with the novel coronavirus. You are fully vaccinated and had a risk contact. However, your responses indicate that the production of antibodies might have been impaired. Therefore, we recommend completion of a PCR-test.

Most users with your answers are not infected with the novel coronavirus. You have encountered a risk contact while being fully vaccinated. In most cases you should be protected (exception: your risk contact is infected with a mutant of the coronavirus; in such a case, a comprehensive medicical consultation is necessary). If you develop symptoms, a PCR-test can be conducted. In such a case, please complete the questionnaire of CovApp again to get an individualized recommendation.

Some users with your answers are infected with the novel coronavirus. Even though you have a negative antigen test, an infection might be possible. We recommend completion of a PCR-test for verfication purposes which has a higher sensitivity and specifity than an antigen test.

Some users with your answers are infected with the novel coronavirus. Even though you have a negative antigen test, an infection might be possible. Your responses indicate typical symptoms of a novel coronavirus infection. We recommend completion of a PCR-test for verfication purposes which has a higher sensitivity and specifity. You are fully vaccinated, however breakthrough infection can occur.

Some users with your answers are infected with the novel coronavirus. Even though you have a negative antigen test, an infection might be possible. We recommend completion of a PCR-test for verfication purposes which has a higher sensitivity and specifity than an antigen test.

Some users with your answers are infected with the novel coronavirus. Even though you have a negative antigen test, an infection might be possible. Your responses indicate typical symptoms of a novel coronavirus infection. We recommend completion of a PCR-test for verfication purposes which has a higher sensitivity and specifity. You are fully vaccinated, however vaccine breakthrough infection can occur.
Many users with your answers are infected with the novel coronavirus. Your responses indicate typical symptoms of a novel coronavirus infection. We recommend completion of a PCR-test.

Your responses indicated that you have many social contacts due to your work or at home. There is no evidence for a risk contact. In your situation, regular antigen-tests might be senseful. If you develop new symptoms or encounter a new risk contact, please complete the questionnaire of CovApp again to get an individualized recommendation.

Most users with your answers are not infected with the novel coronavirus. You might have a higher than average exposition, but you are fully vaccinated and should be protected in most situation. If you develop new symptoms, please complete the questionnaire of CovApp again to get an individualized recommendation.
Many users with your answers are infected with the novel coronavirus. Your responses indicate a risk contact who might have infected you. We recommend completion of a PCR-test.

Most users with your answers are not infected with the novel coronavirus. Currently, there is no necessity to conduct a test.  If you develop new symptoms or encounter a new risk contact, please complete the questionnaire of CovApp again to get an individualized recommendation.
You reported shortness of breath. Please call your general practitioner or the medical on-call service. If your shortness of breath becomes severe, please seek medical help immediately or call 911.

Many users with your responses have a high risk to develop severe COVID-19.

Please seek for medical care immediately, if you have or develop any of the following emergency warning signs:
  • Trouble breathing
  • Pain or pressure in the chest
  • Confusion
  • Inability to wake or stay awake
  • Pale, gray, or blue-colored skin or lips
This list of symptoms and conditions is not complete. Please contact your respective physician or medical provider for any other symptoms.

For additional information, take a look at the CDC guidelines.

Most of the time, vaccination can prevent a severe course of COVID-19. Some users with your responses have an immune system with reduced activity and the inability to create sufficient amounts of antibodies following vaccination. There is no clear evidence for your situation.

Please seek medical care immediately, if your condition deteriorates or you develop any of the following emergency warning signs:
  • Trouble breathing
  • Pain or pressure in the chest
  • Confusion
  • Inability to wake or stay awake
  • Pale, gray, or blue-colored skin or lips
This list of symptoms and conditions is not complete. Please contact your respective physician or medical provider for any other symptoms.

For additional information, take a look at the CDC guidelines.

For most users with your responses vaccination should prevent developing severe COVID-19 despite having risk factors.

Please seek for medical care immediately, if your condition deteriorates or you develop any of the following emergency warning signs:
  • Trouble breathing
  • Pain or pressure in the chest
  • Confusion
  • Inability to wake or stay awake
  • Pale, gray, or blue-colored skin or lips
This list of symptoms and conditions is not complete. Please contact your respective physician or medical provider for any other symptoms.

For additional information, take a look at the CDC guidelines.

Most users with your responses have a low risk to develop severe COVID-19. A modest percentage of people who are fully vaccinated can still get Covid-19 if they are exposed to the novel coronavirus but will most likely develop only mild symptoms.

Many users with your responses have a high risk for severe COVID-19.

High-risk patients benefit particularly from vaccination:
  • Vaccines can keep you from getting and spreading the novel coronavirus.
  • Vaccines help keep you from getting seriously ill.
  • Vaccines can protect people around you.

Vaccines are free and available throughout the US. Please visit Vaccines.gov or call 1-800-232-0233 to find a vaccination site near you.

For more information regarding benefits of vaccination, please also visit CDC.

Most users with your responses have a low risk to develop severe COVID-19. You may still benefit from getting vaccinated:
  • Vaccines can keep you from getting and spreading the novel coronavirus.
  • Vaccines help keep you from getting seriously ill.
  • Vaccines can protect people around you, particulary people with an increased risk of severe illness.

Vaccines are free and available throughout the US. Please visit Vaccines.gov or call 1-800-232-0233 to find a vaccination site near you.

For more information regarding benefits of vaccination, please also visit CDC.
Most users with your responses have a low risk to develop severe COVID-19.

Please self-isolate from other persons to prevent transmission of the virus and follow these rules:

1.) Please stay home except to get medical care. If you need to leave your home, avoid public transportation and wear a mask.
2.) Stay in a separate room and away from other people in your home.
3.) Notify close contacts that they may have been exposed to COVID-19. The novel coronavirus can spread 48 hours before you have developed symptoms or tested positive. By letting your friends and colleagues know, you can prevent further infections and help to protect everyone.
4.) Follow instructions from your healthcare provider and local health department.

For more information, take a look at the CDC guidelines.

Your responses indicate many work-related or private social contacts. Some users with your responses have a breakthrough infection. Please reduce your social interactions as much as possible, until an infection has been ruled out.

For more information, take a look at the CDC guidelines.

Your responses indicate many work-related or private social contacts. Please reduce your social interactions as much as possible, until an infection has been ruled out.

For more information, take a look at the CDC guidelines.

resultCategories.description: Recommendations to prevent spread of virus

results.text:
Suggestion for Monoclonal Antibody Therapy

Users with your responses may benefit from an approved, special treatment with monoclonal antibodies for the novel coronavirus due to a high risk of developing severe COVID-19. Such treatment is currently only available at specialized clinics.

Please coordinate with your respective physician or care provider before contacting a location to receive treatment. A call center is available to answer questions and provide information related to monoclonal antibody therapeutic treatments at the following phone numbers: 1-877-332-6585 (English Language); 1-877-366-0310 (Spanish Language).

testCases.description: Negative PCR should not receive further tests.
Positive PCR and vaccinated should conclude infection, warning and no further test.
Positive PCR and not vaccinated should conculde infection and result in no further testing
Positive Antigen and vaccination should conclude warning and PCR test.
Negative Antigen, no exposition and no symptoms should result in no test.
Negative Antigen, low exposition and no symptoms should result in no test.
High exposition, vaccinated by compromised immunesystem should result in pcr test
High exposition, vaccinated and normal immunesystem should result in no test
Negative Antigen, high exposition, not vaccinated should result in PCR test
No high exposition, negative Antigen, symptoms, vaccinated should result in PCR
No high exposition, negative Antigen, symptoms, not vaccinated should result in PCR
No PCR, no Antigen, symptoms, vaccinated should result in PCR
No PCR, no Antigen, low exposition, no symptoms, not vaccinated should result in Antigen
No PCR, no Antigen, low exposition, no symptoms, vaccinated should result in no testing
No Antigen, No PCR, high exposition, no symptoms, not vaccinated should result in PCR test
Problems breathing should result in physician consultation.
High risk for severe covid-19 and symptoms present, test indicates infection
high risk for severe covid-19 and symptoms present and probable infection
High risk for severe covid-19, no symptoms, no vaccination
